133 wounded | casualties2 = N/A | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Malaya}} }} {{Campaignbox South-East Asian Theatre}} The '''bombing of Singapore''' was an attack on 8 December 1941 by seventeen [[Mitsubishi G3M|G3M ''Nell'']] bombers of Mihoro Air Group (''Mihoro Kaigun [[Kōkūtai]]''),{{citation |title = Full text of "ZERO!"|url = https://archive.org/stream/zero001449mbp/zero001449mbp_djvu.txt|publisher = E. P. Dutton & Co. r Inc.|accessdate = 20 January 2010}} [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service|Imperial Japanese Navy]], flying from [[Thu Dau Mot]] in southern [[Indochina]]. The attack began at around 0430, shortly after Japanese forces [[Japanese Invasion of Malaya|landed on Kota Bharu]], [[British Malaya|Malaya]]. It was the first knowledge the [[Singapore]] population had that [[World War II|war]] had broken out in the [[South-East Asian theatre of World War II|Far East]]. ==Background== The attack on Singapore was assigned to 34 bombers of [[Genzan Air Group]] (''Genzan Kaigun Kōkūtai'') and 31 bombers of Mihoro Air Group. Their targets were [[Tengah Air Base|RAF Tengah]], [[Seletar Airport|RAF Seletar]], [[Singapore Naval Base|Sembawang Naval Base]] and [[Keppel Harbour]].{{citation|title = Imperial Japanese Navy Air Assault of Singapore|url = http://www.aircraftresourcecenter.com/Fea1/801-900/Fea854_Singapore-Assualt_Yeo/00.shtm|publisher = Mike Yeo|accessdate = 20 January 2010|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100210235021/http://aircraftresourcecenter.com/Fea1/801-900/Fea854_Singapore-Assualt_Yeo/00.shtm#|archive-date = 10 February 2010|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}} Six squadrons from both air groups took off from southern Indochina on the night of 7 December 1941. However, bad weather conditions were encountered while over the [[South China Sea]]. Thick clouds offered poor visibility for the pilots, while rough winds caused most of the formations to become separated. After several attempts to regroup failed, [[Lieutenant Commander]] Niichi Nakanishi, [[Wing Commander (rank)|Wing Commander]] of Genzan Air Group, ordered them to abort mission and return to base, thereby reducing the impact of a much heavier raid. Only seventeen G3M bombers of Mihoro Air Group reached Singapore on schedule, unobstructed by bad weather. ===The Attack=== The Japanese formation was detected by a radar station in [[Mersing]], [[British Malaya|Malaya]], almost an hour before they reached Singapore. Three [[Brewster Buffalo]] fighters of [[No. 453 Squadron RAAF]] were on standby at [[RAF Sembawang]]. However, Flight Lieutenant [[Tim Vigors]]' request to [[Scrambling (military)|scramble]] and intercept the Japanese bombers was denied.Stenman and Thomas, page 45 [[Air Chief Marshal]] [[Robert Brooke-Popham]] feared that the anti-aircraft batteries would fire on the friendly fighters, despite Vigors being an experienced [[night fighter]] in the [[Battle of Britain]]. He was supplemented by the belief that the Buffalo fighter was only suited for daylight fighting and could not be used at night. Paradoxically, there were 12 [[Bristol Blenheim]] Mark IF night fighters of [[No. 27 Squadron RAF]] stationed in [[Sungai Petani]], Malaya, but were being used as [[ground-attack aircraft]].Burton 2006, page 97 The streets were still brightly lit despite [[civil defense siren|air raid siren]]s going off at 0400, allowing pilot [[navigator]]s to locate their targets without difficulty. [[Air Raid Precautions]] (ARP) Headquarters was not even manned, and there was no blackout as police and [[power station]] officials could not find the employee who had the key to the switch (only two practice blackouts were conducted in September 1941 before the raid). When the bombers began their attack at 0430, Allied anti-aircraft guns immediately opened fire. The battleship [[HMS Prince of Wales (53)|''Prince of Wales'']] and battlecruiser [[HMS Repulse (1916)|''Repulse'']] also responded, but no aircraft was shot down. A formation of nine bombers flew over without releasing their bombs to draw the searchlights and anti-aircraft guns away from the other group. They were flying at 12,000 feet, while the second formation was at 4,000 feet.Owen 2001, page 36 ===Aftermath=== [[File:Mihoro G3M.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mitsubishi G3M]] ''Nell'' of Mihoro Air Group, carrying bombs externally.]] [[File:Air raid shelter.jpg|thumb|left|Civilians hiding in an air raid shelter at [[Tiong Bahru Estate]] during a Japanese bombing raid in December 1941.]] [[File:Women & dead child.jpg|thumb|Two women grieving over a child killed in an air raid at [[Jinrikisha Station]] on 3 February 1942.]] The 'Raiders Passed' signal was sent out at 0500. The bombers succeeded in bombing the airfields at Seletar and Tengah, damaging three [[Bristol Blenheim]] bombers of [[No. 34 Squadron RAF]]. A number of bombs also fell on [[Raffles Place]]. 61 people were killed and more than 700 were injured. Most of the casualties were troops of the 2/2nd Gurkha Rifles, [[11th Indian Infantry Division]]. The Japanese bombers all returned safely to Thu Dau Mot.{{citation|title = First bomb raid on Singapore|url = http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_7_2005-01-25.html|publisher = Chua, Jeanne|date = 29 September 1997|access-date = 20 January 2010|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081226134341/http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_7_2005-01-25.html|archive-date = 26 December 2008|url-status = dead}} Though the bombing caused only minor damage to the airfields, it stunned the [[British Far East Command]]. Despite intelligence reports of Japanese aircraft performance in the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]], the command did not believe Japan's air forces were capable of striking Singapore from airfields more than 600 miles away in Indochina. The raid came as a surprise to [[Lieutenant General]] [[Arthur Percival]], who "hardly expected the Japanese to have any very long-range aircraft."Burton 2006, page 96 {{cquote|Rudely awakened in the small hours of the morning by the screams of air raid sirens and the roar of ack ack guns and in the clear moonlit sky around a formation of Japanese bombers. Bombs were dropped but none fell in our area. So the war in the Far East started – all day we heard news bulletins telling of the wide spread treachery of the Japs – Well! They've asked for it – !! – Diary and 'Line' book written by the pilots of [[No. 453 Squadron RAAF]]{{citation|title = The RAAF in Malaya|url = http://www.ww2australia.gov.au/japadvance/raafMalaya.html|publisher = ww2australia.gov.au|accessdate = 15 January 2010|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091007221820/http://www.ww2australia.gov.au//japadvance/raafMalaya.html|archive-date = 7 October 2009|url-status = dead}}}} Singapore had respite from further air raids while the Japanese focussed their attacks on Allied positions in northern Malaya. The next raid occurred on the night of 16/17 December 1941. This was minor attack on RAF Tengah by two Japanese Ki-21s. The next serious raid on Singapore City was on the night of 29/30 December. The Japanese launched their first daylight raid on 12 January 1942, a day after their capture of Kuala Lumpur allowed them to shift aircraft of the [[Imperial Japanese Army Air Service|IJAAF]] to southern Malaya. ==See also== *[[Battle of Singapore]] *[[Bombing of Singapore (1944–45)]] ==References== ===Citations=== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{Refbegin}} *Lee, G.
